title: Eoghan Grace
text:
Eoghan Grace (born 6 October 1987) is an Irish former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Career.
Grace began his professional rugby career as a member of his native province <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster's</a> academy, and during that time he won a <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28rugby%20union%29">grand slam</a> with the <a href="Ireland%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland under-20s</a> team during the 2007 <a href="Six%20Nations%20Under%2020s%20Championship">Six Nations Under 20s Championship</a> and an <a href="All-Ireland%20League%20%28rugby%20union%29">All-Ireland League Division 1</a> title with <a href="Shannon%20RFC">Shannon</a> in 2008–09. However, Grace was unable to break into Munster's senior squad, and he moved to England to join <a href="Premiership%20Rugby">Premiership Rugby</a> side <a href="Exeter%20Chiefs">Exeter Chiefs</a> ahead of the 2010–11 season. Grace's time with the Devon club was hampered by an achilles injury, and after one season with Exeter, Grace returned to Ireland to join <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a>. He stayed with the western province for two seasons, which were also hampered by injury, before returning to <a href="Devon">Devon</a> to join <a href="Plymouth%20Albion%20R.F.C.">Plymouth Albion</a>, where he lodged with fellow former Munsterman <a href="Declan%20Cusack">Declan Cusack</a>.
After two seasons with Plymouth, Grace joined another <a href="RFU%20Championship">RFU Championship</a> side, <a href="Ealing%20Trailfinders%20Rugby%20Club">Ealing Trailfinders</a>, for the 2015–16 season. At the beginning of the 2016–17 season, Grace signed for <a href="Coventry%20R.F.C.">Coventry</a> and was appointed co-captain of the club, before ending his career back with Plymouth, whilst also coaching in the club's academy and community programme. After rugby, Grace began running two companies; "Eolas+", a not-for-profit that goes into primary schools and runs holiday camps in the south-west of England to get children involved in sports, and "Pro Rugby Academy", which works with aspiring rugby players who have missed out on contracts with professional clubs.
